title: 106_hr2298
content:
The "Equity for Temporary Workers Act of 1999" prohibits discrimination in wages, hours, and benefits for temporary employees. After working 1,000 hours in a 12-month period, temporary employees are entitled to the same benefits as permanent employees. The "Equity for Temporary Workers Act of 1999" prohibits wage discrimination based on employment status within an establishment. Temporary employees must be paid the same rate as full-time employees for equal work, unless justified by seniority, merit, production quantity/quality, or other non-employment status factors. The "Equity for Temporary Workers Act of 1999" prohibits wage discrimination based on employment status. Employers cannot reduce wages to comply with the law. Labor organizations cannot cause discrimination. Unpaid wages are considered unpaid minimum wages or overtime compensation. The term "labor organization" includes any organization representing employees. Employee representation committee or plan involving employers dealing with grievances, labor disputes, wages, rates of pay, hours, or work conditions. SEC. 4. LIABILITY TO ALL PERSONS ON WORKSITE. Amends Section 5(a)(1) of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 to ensure employers provide a hazard-free workplace to prevent death or serious harm to employees. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT. Any employer violating section 2 or 3 is liable to affected employees for damages equal to lost wages, benefits, plus interest and liquidated damages. An employer who violates section 2 or 3 may have their liability reduced if they can prove good faith and reasonable grounds for their actions. Equitable relief such as reinstatement and promotion may also be granted. An action to recover damages or relief can be pursued. The equitable relief prescribed in paragraph (1) can be sought against any employer in Federal or State court by employees on behalf of themselves or others similarly situated. The court may award attorney's fees, expert witness fees, and other costs to be paid by the defendant. The right to bring an action on behalf of an employee terminates upon the filing of a complaint by the Secretary in a related action. The Secretary can take action to resolve complaints of violations of employee rights, seeking payment delays or damages from responsible employers. The action must not be dismissed without prejudice. The Secretary can investigate and resolve complaints of violations of sections 2 or 3 similar to how complaints of violations of sections 6 and 7 are handled under the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. The Secretary may bring a civil action to recover damages, with any recovered sums to be paid directly to affected employees or deposited into the Treasury if not paid within 3 years. The Secretary can investigate and resolve complaints of violations of sections 2 or 3 under the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. An action may be brought within 2 years of the last event constituting the alleged violation, or within 3 years for a willful violation. The Secretary can commence an action for injunction in district courts. The district courts have jurisdiction to restrain violations of sections 2 or 3, including withholding of payment to eligible employees, and to provide equitable relief such as reinstatement and promotion. The Solicitor of Labor can represent the Secretary in litigation under this section. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, key definitions include:
- Employee: an individual working under a contract with an employer for at least 1,000 hours per year.
- Employer: a person with 100 or more employees for 20 or more weeks in a year.
- Permanent employee: hired indefinitely with benefits.
- Secretary: the Secretary of Labor. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Labor. A "temporary agency" is a person who procures employees for an employer temporarily. A "temporary employee" is not a permanent employee.
